columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the present value of the stock price based on the given conditions.

This problem uses the concept of nonconstant growth which basically means that the value of the given dividend does not linearly increase over time but instead it fluctuates. 

In order to solve this, we need to determine the year when the company will reach the industry average of $5\%$ growth rate on the dividends. To do this, we will simply use $20\%$ for the first year and continue to subtract $5\%$ every year until it reaches the industry average. This means that it will take $4$ years until the company reaches the average.

Since we know that it will be $4$ years, we will then solve for the dividend price for Year 1 until Year 4. We can do this by taking the previous dividend and multiplying it by 1 plus the current rate.

For Year 1:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend}&=\$3.15 \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$3.78
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend}&=\$3.78 \times (1+0.15)\\
&=\$4.35
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 3:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend}&=\$4.35 \times (1+0.10)\\
&=\$4.79
\end{aligned}$$

For Year 4:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Dividend}&=\$4.79 \times (1+0.05)\\
&=\$5.03
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have the dividends for each of the Years, we will take the present value. To do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\text{Future value} \times \dfrac{1}{(1+\text{Required rate of return})^\text{Number of periods}}
\end{aligned}$$

Substituting the values, we will get the following:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value for Year 1}&=\$3.78 \times\dfrac{1}{(1+0.12)^1}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3.36\\
\\
\text{Present value for Year 2}&=\$4.35 \times\dfrac{1}{(1+0.12)^2}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3.47\\
\\
\text{Present value for Year 3}&=\$4.79 \times\dfrac{1}{(1+0.12)^3}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3.41\\
\\
\text{Present value for Year 4}&=\$5.03 \times\dfrac{1}{(1+0.12)^4}\\[15 pt]
&=\$3.20\\
\end{aligned}$$

We will then get the present value of the share price by using the formula in Step 4:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\$75.45 \times \dfrac{1}{(1+0.12)^4}\\[15 pt]
&=\$47.95
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have the present value for the share price at Year 4, we can simply add the present value of the dividends in Step 4 to this value to get the current share price.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Current share price}&=\$47.95+\$3.36+\$3.47+\$3.41+\$3.20\\
&=\$61.39
\end{aligned}$$

The current price of a company's stock is $\$61.39$.
